Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Hybrid Sputtering/e-beam Thin Film Deposition System for Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award to the State University of New York at Buffalo (UB) is for the acquisition of a hybrid sputtering/e-beam thin film deposition system. The instrument will be used by an interdisciplinary group of UB faculty from four different departments: Physics, Chemistry, Chemical & Biological Engineering, and Electrical Engineering. The instrument is capable of depositing multilayer thin films combining metal, semiconductor, and insulator materials, in situ device fabrication and in situ characterization of a broad range of physical properties. It will enable the exploration of novel energy-related materials and devices, spin effects and materials in solid state devices, electronic materials and sensors, and optical materials. These materials and devices will contribute to applications ranging from solar cells and batteries, data storage to biological sensing.

The hybrid sputtering/e-beam thin film deposition system will foster cross-disciplinary interactions, and realize previously undiscovered synergies in research. It is an important addition to UB's material research infrastructure and is a key priority for the newly planned Materials Science and Engineering Ph.D. program as it will help to attract new faculty members from various fields strategic to the University. The instrument will be house in the Integrated Nanostructured Systems Instrument Facility where it will be available to the broader UB research community and regional companies and institutions. A large number of post-doctoral scholars, and graduate and undergraduate students will gain hands-on experience in the operation and maintenance of what has become an essential tool in modern materials research. A new course will be developed concentrating on nanoscale materials and devices. The PIs will work closely with Buffalo State College and UB's Cora P. Maloney College to involve underrepresented groups in research using the instrument.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The thin film deposition system is a dual chamber system with a sputtering chamber and an electron beam evaporation chamber connected through a transfer chamber. The system was installed in May 2013. The system was upgraded to include one additional RF sputtering source and one Quartz crystal thickness monitor at the sputtering side. A large number of active research groups will benefit from the installed facility. The instrument currently supports several groups from collage of Arts and Sciences and School of Applied Science and Engineering, with research topics ranging from thin film solar cells, spin based electronics, THz devices, optical matamaterials with applications in sensors and detectors as well as energy harvesting. With completion of the setup of the facility account, the instrument is expected to support more than 20 PIs across the campus, as well as researchers from nearby institutions including Alfred University, Buffalo State College as well as industrial partners such as from SEMATECH. A website has been developed about the instrument facility, including its capabilities, deposition tips, recipes for common materials, and a Calendar for reservation. Three manuscripts have been submitted, with the results obtained from the facility.

 The acquisition of a hybrid sputtering/e-beam thin film deposition system and its subsequent use by faculty and students in many different fields will foster cross-disciplinary interactions, and realize previously undiscovered synergies in research. It is a key priority for the newly planned Materials Science and Engineering Ph.D. program and will help to attract new faculty members from various fields strategic to UB. It will also be an important addition to UB’s material research infrastructure INSIF and be made available to the broader UB research community. 6 graduate students were trained to operate the instrument during the installation, including the sputtering function, e-beam evaporation, sample transfer through the load-lock, RHEED detector operation, and routine maintenance procedures.  Between May and October 2013, the PI’s lab provided training to a total of 12 graduate students from 8 research groups across departments from College of Arts and Sciences and School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. 8 students are authorized to operate the instrument independently. These skills are highly relevant to the high tech industry. The instrumentation is further expected to facilitate collaborations with regional and industrial partners-the business development officer at the Center of Excellence in Materials Informatics has been advertising these capabilities to industrial partners.
